Now suppose we want to start at some value of the index besides 0. We would like to find a way to sum the following: \sum_{\ell=k}^{n-1} at^{\ell}

task.p: Find the greatest common factor of all of the terms we are adding, and factor it out. It might help to write the series out in long form, but write your final factored expression using summation notation.

Now we substitute a new index m in place of \ell. This is called re-indexing, and is similar to integration by substitution (without worrying about dx). Find an equation for the new index m in terms of \ell, make the substitution (change the lower and upper bounds of the sum, and the terms of the sum), and rewrite the result. Then sum.

Now we will find the present value of an annuity (actually, an annuity-immediate). The following timeline represents an annuity in which there are n periodic payments of K, paid at the end of each period. Assume \iota is the effective periodic interest rate, and v is the corresponding present value factor.

figure.caption: Timeline for an annuity with n regular payments of K, paid at the end of the period.

introduction.p: The present value is denoted Ka_{\angln \iota}, although (as in this timeline) this is shortened to Ka_{\angln} when the interest rate is understood. As indicated in the timeline, this is the value at time 0, one period before the first payment.

task.p: Write the present value as the sum of the present values of each payment (this is called the series representation). Be careful about where your sum begins and ends!
Use what we have learned in this activity to find a closed-form formula for the sum.

Note the following: \frac{v}{1-v} = \frac{1}{\iota} (Can you show why this is true?) Use this identity to rewrite your result for Ka_{\angln \iota}. This is the present value formula for an annuity immediate.
